meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Two</kanji> times <kanji>ten</kanji> <kanji>years old</kanji> is <vocabulary>twenty years old</vocabulary>.

Since 〜歳 can be replaced with 〜才, 二十歳 can also be written 二十才. Either way, it still means you're officially an adult in Japan… even if you don't feel like one yet.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>smash</kanji> and the verb vocab version of the kanji is <vocabulary>to smash</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to break</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cook</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to cook</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to boil</vocabulary>. Often it has to do with cooking grains (<vocabulary>to cook grains</vocabulary>).

Even though you have this <kanji>habit</kanji> you're still able to win. That's why this is <vocabulary>And yet</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>though</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>in spite of</vocabulary>. Because, <vocabulary>in spite of</vocabulary> your bad habit, you still won. Frustrating.
The <kanji>Empire</kanji> (帝国) <kanji>ism</kanji> (主義) is when you are doing <vocabulary>imperialism</vocabulary>. Long live the emperor!
You know that 椅子 is a "chair." What about a <kanji>car</kanji> <kanji>chair</kanji>? It's a chair with wheels. A <vocabulary>wheelchair</vocabulary>.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: Edge Of A Sumo Wrestling Ring

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 土俵 is a sumo ring? Now you're at its <kanji>edge</kanji>, which means this is the <vocabulary>edge of a sumo ring</vocabulary>. This can also refer to a <vocabulary>last moment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>critical moment</vocabulary> in time, like the moment before you get pushed out of the ring.

When you're <kanji>distract</kanji>ed, everything you do is a <vocabulary>fluke</vocabulary>. You're not focusing, so it all comes down to <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is mostly written in kana only!

The thing that will <kanji>threaten</kanji> and then <kanji>urge</kanji> you to do something else is the <vocabulary>threat</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>menace</vocabulary>.

Note that 脅迫 often involves overt and serious threats that may cross legal boundaries.

You know that 魔法 is "magic" so what about someone who <kanji>use</kanji>s <kanji>magic</kanji>? What are they called? How about a <vocabulary>wizard</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>witch</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>sorcerer</vocabulary>?

I need something to <kanji>provide</kanji> for me in an emergency, so I'm <kanji>amass</kanji>ing <vocabulary>emergency stores</vocabulary>. I'm building up a <vocabulary>stockpile</vocabulary> of <vocabulary>reserves</vocabulary>, just in case.

備蓄 is a formal word for stockpiling or reserving supplies for future use, especially in preparation for emergencies or shortages. It's commonly used for storing food, water, fuel, or other necessities in case of disasters.
Take your <kanji>savings</kanji> and <kanji>amass</kanji> them. That is your <vocabulary>savings</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>amass</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to store up</vocabulary> — as in gradually gathering and keeping something so it's there when you need it.

This often relates to storing up food or supplies. In the same vein, it can mean <vocabulary>to amass</vocabulary> a fortune for later use, or <vocabulary>to build up</vocabulary> things like stamina and knowledge to slowly prepare yourself for something. You can even say ヒゲを蓄える (to build up or grow facial hair). Readiness comes in many forms, you know?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>mosquito</kanji> <kanji>notebook</kanji>, for some reason, is a <vocabulary>mosquito net</vocabulary>. Think of a notebook with graph paper lines on it, perhaps. These lines are shaped like a net. Surround yourself with it to make your own <vocabulary>mosquito net</vocabulary>.
Please <kanji>record</kanji> it in the <kanji>notebook</kanji>. This will be the <vocabulary>registry</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>notebook</kanji> is a notebook you can hold in your hand. This could simply be a <vocabulary>notebook</vocabulary>, but it could also be a <vocabulary>planner</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>memo</kanji> (メモ) <kanji>notebook</kanji> is a <vocabulary>memo book</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>memo pad</vocabulary> that you use to write notes in.
A <kanji>telephone</kanji> (電話) <kanji>notebook</kanji> is a book you use with your telephone. It's a <vocabulary>telephone book</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>telephone directory</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>paste</kanji> so the verb vocab is <vocabulary>to paste</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>to stick</vocabulary>).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>humiliate</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to humiliate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to disgrace</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word to describe an action that damages someone's reputation or makes them feel deeply ashamed, often in public situations. In some contexts, this can also imply sexual assault, so it should be used with caution.
If you <kanji>shame</kanji> and <kanji>humiliate</kanji> me, I will have a sense of <vocabulary>disgrace</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>shame</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Yield</kanji> a <kanji>humiliat</kanji>ion onto your life. What a <vocabulary>disgrace</vocabulary>. What a <vocabulary>humiliation</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Start a <kanji>fire</kanji> in your <kanji>flower pot</kanji> to make a <vocabulary>brazier</vocabulary>. A nice, homemade brazier. It might ruin the aesthetics of your garden, but at least you'll be warm. (Or you might just burn down your house.)

Above your <kanji>flower pot</kanji> hangs a <kanji>scroll</kanji>, but it's not just there for decoration — you can also use it as a <vocabulary>headband</vocabulary> when you're gardening! Planting flowers is sweaty work, after all, and a good headband can make all the difference.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>dark</kanji> <kanji>darkness</kanji> is a <vocabulary>darkness</vocabulary>. It's <vocabulary>the dark</vocabulary>.

"<kanji>Darkness</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> to worry about," I said <vocabulary>thoughtlessly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unreasonably</vocabulary>. Of course darkness is worth worrying about. It's darkness! Who knows what is in there!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>crevice</kanji> <kanji>interval</kanji> is an area with a <vocabulary>crevice</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crack</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

One person <kanji>starve</kanji>s and another person <kanji>starve</kanji>s. Then more people. So much starve that there's <vocabulary>starvation</vocabulary> going on. It's <vocabulary>famine</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hunger</vocabulary>, everywhere.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>starve</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to starve</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word and it's often used in phrases like 愛情に飢える (<vocabulary>to be starved for</vocabulary> love) or 知識に飢える (<vocabulary>to have a thirst for</vocabulary> knowledge).
<kanji>Starve</kanji> to <kanji>death</kanji> is <vocabulary>death from starvation</vocabulary>... <vocabulary>Starving to death</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Livestock</kanji> will <kanji>give birth</kanji> to more livestock. You're in the biz of <vocabulary>livestock farming</vocabulary>, that's why. This is <vocabulary>animal husbandry</vocabulary>.

畜産 is a formal agricultural term, often used in discussions about farming industries, food production, and environmental impact.
<kanji>House</kanji> broken <kanji>livestock</kanji> are <vocabulary>domestic animals</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>livestock</vocabulary>. They're made to live with us in or near our homes.
The <kanji>livestock</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji>. The life of a <vocabulary>beast</vocabulary>! Arghhh, <vocabulary>damnit</vocabulary>, I hate the life of a beast. Damnit.

Things that are <kanji>swift</kanji> and <kanji>fast</kanji> are going to be <vocabulary>quick</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fast</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rapid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>swift</vocabulary>. So many quick things.
A <kanji>horse riding</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is also known as a <vocabulary>knight</vocabulary>. Onward, knights of the round! Off to find the holy grail!

手 takes its alternative meaning "doer" here, so that gives us <kanji>horse riding</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji>. Who does horse riding? It’s a <vocabulary>jockey</vocabulary>.

This word usually refers to a professional or skilled rider in horse racing or equestrian sports.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>use up</kanji> or <kanji>exhaust</kanji>, and this verb is <vocabulary>to be used up</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be exhausted</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Reason</kanji> is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>exhaust</kanji>ed... but what you're asking is <vocabulary>unreasonable</vocabulary>. Soon my reason will be exhausted, though.
If you <kanji>exhaust</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> you are putting out <vocabulary>efforts</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>coloring</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to color something</vocabulary>, because you're doing coloring.
The <kanji>color</kanji> <kanji>coloring</kanji> is the <vocabulary>color</vocabulary> of something.
<kanji>Astray</kanji> <kanji>coloring</kanji> is coloring that's all over the place. It's astray all over your clothes. This astray coloring is <vocabulary>camouflage</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>coloring</kanji> <kanji>painting</kanji> is a <vocabulary>watercolor painting</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Oil</kanji> <kanji>coloring</kanji> is better known as <vocabulary>oil painting</vocabulary>. What fine strokes! What fine lines!

When you <kanji>record</kanji> <kanji>recollection</kanji>s in your mind, that concept is the concept of <vocabulary>memory</vocabulary>. This word is not a specific memory, instead it's the idea of memory itself. So, uh, try to memorize that.
A <kanji>recollection</kanji> and <kanji>measure</kanji>ment of the situation is what I use to make a <vocabulary>guess</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>speculation</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>melt</kanji> and this word means <vocabulary>to melt something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to melt</vocabulary>. You're doing the melting, and you know it because you are the <reading>cause</reading> (かす) of the melting.
It can <kanji>melt</kanji> a <kanji>boulder</kanji>? What is this stuff that's so hot? It's <vocabulary>lava</vocabulary>. It's also probably made from melted boulders too, come to think of it.

With <kanji>water</kanji> it will <kanji>melt</kanji>. It is <kanji>natural</kanji>ly like this. It is <vocabulary>water soluble</vocabulary>.

水溶性 is a scientific and technical term that refers to <vocabulary>water solubility</vocabulary>. It's commonly used in chemistry, medicine, and product descriptions.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>resistant</kanji>. If you're resisting things, then you're enduring and withstanding them. That's why this is <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to withstand</vocabulary>.
I'm <kanji>resistant</kanji> and I <kanji>endure</kanji>. I have much <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>perseverance</vocabulary>.
If something is <kanji>resistant</kanji> to <kanji>heat</kanji> then it is <vocabulary>heat resistant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>heatproof</vocabulary>.
If something is <kanji>resistant</kanji> to <kanji>fire</kanji> then it is <vocabulary>fire resistant</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fireproof</vocabulary>. Turtles are not this.
I have the <kanji>nature</kanji> of being <kanji>resistant</kanji> for a <kanji>long time</kanji>. Things that are resistant for a long time have good <vocabulary>durability</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dance</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to dance</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>dance</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dance</vocabulary>.

While a <kanji>dance</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> can be a location in which you dance, this word actually means <vocabulary>landing</vocabulary> (as in, a landing between two flights of stairs on a staircase) or <vocabulary>plateau</vocabulary> (as in, for example, a plateauing economy) most of the time.

While the meaning has changed over time to mostly refer to landings on staircases, it can still be used to mean <vocabulary>dance hall</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>dance floor</vocabulary>, although loanwords like ダンスホール are more commonly used these days.

The <kanji>ancestral festival</kanji> <kanji>dance</kanji> is the <vocabulary>ancestral festival dance</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>bon festival dance</vocabulary>.

盆踊り (<vocabulary>bon odori</vocabulary>) is a festival dance performed for Obon, a Buddhist event that honors the spirits of one's ancestors. In this dance, people often wear yukata and dance in circles around a central platform, moving in synchronized patterns. It's a fun time, be sure to attend one if you can!

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>clever</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>clever</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>intelligent</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>wise</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sage</vocabulary>! Or you can just be straightforward and call them a <vocabulary>wise person</vocabulary>. 

賢人 is a somewhat old-fashioned word used to describe someone with deep knowledge or good judgment. It has a dignified, antiquated feel that makes you think of wise figures in old legends or classical literature.

You're <kanji>wise</kanji> and <kanji>bright</kanji> so obviously you're going to make <vocabulary>wise</vocabulary> decisions too — <vocabulary>sensible</vocabulary> in every regard. In fact, when you make these very wise choices and judgment calls, your brain glows brightly.

賢明 is a formal word that is often seen in writing. It's commonly used to say how someone made a wise decision or sensible choice.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>radiance</kanji>. Imagine if something is radiating on something else. That would cause it <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to glitter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to sparkle</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>light</kanji>'s <kanji>radiance</kanji> is that of <vocabulary>brightness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendor</vocabulary>.

光輝 can refer to both physical radiance or to the metaphorical brilliance of someone's achievements. It's a formal word used mostly in advanced written contexts, but you may also come across it as a name (usually for males) in everyday life.

The <kanji>radiance</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s show the <vocabulary>luminance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>brightness</vocabulary> of something.

This is a technical term used in physics. It refers to the amount of light reflected or emitted from a surface.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, but it also means <vocabulary>cannabis</vocabulary> as well.
<kanji>Big</kanji> <kanji>hemp</kanji> is <vocabulary>marijuana</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cannabis</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>hemp</kanji> <kanji>drunk</kanji>ness is when you take some "hemp" and put it into your body so you don't really feel anything anymore. This is <vocabulary>anesthesia</vocabulary>.

The meaning of this noun is the same as the kanji: <vocabulary>lamp</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>light</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>torch</vocabulary> as well, depending on the context.
The <kanji>streets</kanji> are lit by <kanji>lamp</kanji>s — <vocabulary>streetlight</vocabulary>s, to be specific! And nighttime in the city sure would be a lot scarier without them.
An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>lamp</kanji> is an <vocabulary>electric lamp</vocabulary>. Nowadays they're all electricity, though, which means it's a <vocabulary>lamp</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>blossom</kanji> or <kanji>bloom</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to bloom</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>slow</kanji> <kanji>bloom</kanji> is a bloom that happens late. It's a <vocabulary>late flower</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>late blooming</vocabulary>. Important to know if you're going to go do 花見.
The <kanji>return</kanji> <kanji>blossom</kanji> is when the blossoms return. A <vocabulary>second bloom</vocabulary>. This is another word for a <vocabulary>comeback</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cultivate</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to cultivate</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Cultivate</kanji> and <kanji>foster</kanji> something. That's <vocabulary>cultivation</vocabulary>.

The kanji is <kanji>regret</kanji> and this is <vocabulary>regrettable</vocabulary>. And something regrettable is likely to be <vocabulary>frustrating</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>vexing</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>disappointing</vocabulary>.

悔しい generally expresses a feeling of frustration, regret, or vexation, often due to a sense of failure or missed opportunity. It conveys a strong emotional response to a situation where one feels disappointed or bitter about not achieving something they desired, especially when they were close to success or when the outcome feels unfair.
My <kanji>behind</kanji> <kanji>regret</kanji> is the regret from before, which is all regret. So this means <vocabulary>regret</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>repentance</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

If you look to your <kanji>armpit</kanji> to <kanji>see</kanji> you're <vocabulary>looking away</vocabulary> from where you should be looking. If you're too busy staring at your armpit while you drive, for example, you'll probably get in an accident. So don't look away like this!

If you're on <kanji>armpit</kanji> <kanji>duty</kanji> you're definitely not the lead. You're standing next to the lead's armpit, because you're the <vocabulary>supporting actor</vocabulary>. You're in a <vocabulary>supporting role</vocabulary>.

When you try something but can <kanji>not yet</kanji> <kanji>accomplish</kanji> it, it's only an <vocabulary>attempt</vocabulary> that failed or stayed incomplete. That's 未遂, and it's often used in legal contexts for crimes that didn't succeed.
<kanji>Accomplish</kanji> and <kanji>go</kanji> forth! These are your <vocabulary>accomplishment</vocabulary>s. This is your <vocabulary>execution</vocabulary> of actions.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>squad</kanji> <kanji>leader</kanji> is the <vocabulary>squad leader</vocabulary>. Can also be the <vocabulary>honcho</vocabulary> (ever wonder where this word came from?).
Let's <kanji>paint</kanji> a <kanji>cloth</kanji>'s worth of paint on the wall. This is one <vocabulary>application</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>coating</vocabulary> of paint.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>paint</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to paint</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to plaster</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to lacquer</vocabulary>.
With <kanji>paint</kanji> I want to <kanji>attire</kanji> the wall. Let's put a <vocabulary>coating</vocabulary> of <vocabulary>painting</vocabulary> up on the wall.

<kanji>Paint</kanji> <kanji>material</kanji> is <vocabulary>paint</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>painting material</vocabulary>.

塗料 refers to the paint or <vocabulary>coating</vocabulary> used for surfaces like walls or industrial items to decorate or protect them.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>diagonal</kanji> <kanji>surface</kanji> is a <vocabulary>slant</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>slope</vocabulary>.
When text has a <kanji>diagonal</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> to it, it is leaning. It is in <vocabulary>italics</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>italic font style</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>punch</kanji>, so the verb means <vocabulary>to punch</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to strike</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to hit</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>punch</kanji> <kanji>hit</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>strike</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>blow</vocabulary>. Not a friendly hit, that's for sure.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>spear</kanji> and a <kanji>shield</kanji>. Totally different things. Not at all like each other. A complete <vocabulary>contradiction</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>rear</kanji> <kanji>shield</kanji> is the shield that protects your back. This is your <vocabulary>backing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>support</vocabulary>. So, not a literal shield, but the kind of protection that you want to have anyways.
<kanji>Obtain</kanji> a <kanji>harvest</kanji>. When you do this you have a <vocabulary>harvest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crop</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means <vocabulary>to get spilled</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to fall out</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to overflow</vocabulary>.
